Fighting game fans are a confused bunch. Some are Smash purists, others swear by Street Fighter, and most spend their days ranking their mains in reddit tier lists. I think they should try maining the shower. Amongst the depraved and dark path of the fighting game community, Brawlhalla offers a breath of fresh air. Yes, the community is toxic, yes, the game has a ridiculously high skill floor, and yes, it‚Äôs not balanced. But it‚Äôs not Smash. And that must count for something, right?Brawlhalla is a quirky, fun, and addictive fighting game that stands proudly on its own. With its cartoony graphics, diverse legends, and cross-play feature, it‚Äôs perfect for settling those ‚ÄúX is the best fighting game‚Äù debates. If you're looking for a game that offers a unique, high-paced spin on its stale genre, then Brawlhalla is the way to go.

Having spent hundreds of hours in Brawlhalla, I can confidently say it‚Äôs a game packed with memorable moments.One of the best aspects of Brawlhalla is its vibrant and diverse character roster. As an Arcadia main, I've loved Riding my beetle into battle. Learning the different legends is challenging but incredibly rewarding. The game shines brightest when playing with friends‚Äîthere‚Äôs nothing like teaming up, pulling off coordinated moves, and celebrating with emotes after a hard-fought match. These moments of shared victory and fun are what make Brawlhalla so special.The matchmaking system can sometimes be frustrating, occasionally pairing you with players far beyond your skill level. The game‚Äôs learning curve means that mastering combos and reading players is essential, and there will be moments of intense rage. ( uhm.. apologies to my desk that had to take my beatings) But these challenges are part of the journey and make your progress all the more satisfying.Brawlhalla remains one of my favorite games. It's very addictive, combined with the joy of playing and strategizing with friends, makes it a standout in the fighting game genre.If you're looking for a game that's both challenging and incredibly fun, Brawlhalla is definitely worth diving into. Just be prepared for a wild ride, and remember that every moment of rage is a step towards becoming a better player!

Review of Brawlhalla‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê | An Engaging and Accessible Platform Fighter with Endless FunBrawlhalla, developed by Blue Mammoth Games and published by Ubisoft, is a free-to-play platform fighter that has carved out a significant niche in the genre since its release in 2017. With its diverse roster of characters, accessible gameplay mechanics, and a robust online community, Brawlhalla offers a dynamic and enjoyable fighting experience for both casual players and competitive enthusiasts. Here‚Äôs why Brawlhalla deserves a strong 4-star rating:Pros:1. Diverse Roster of Legends:Brawlhalla features a diverse and ever-expanding roster of Legends, each with unique abilities, weapons, and playstyles.* From sword-wielding knights to futuristic blasters, the game offers a character to suit every player‚Äôs preference. The distinct designs and varied move sets ensure that each Legend feels unique, encouraging players to experiment and find their favorite fighter. Regular updates introducing new Legends keep the roster fresh and exciting, adding to the game‚Äôs longevity.2. Accessible and Fun Gameplay:The gameplay mechanics in Brawlhalla are accessible and easy to pick up, making it a great entry point for newcomers to the platform fighting genre. The controls are intuitive, allowing players to perform a variety of moves and combos with ease. The game‚Äôs simplicity doesn‚Äôt come at the expense of depth, as there is plenty of room for mastering advanced techniques and strategies. This balance of accessibility and depth creates a fun and engaging experience for players of all skill levels.3. Variety of Game Modes and Events:Brawlhalla offers a wide range of game modes that cater to different playstyles and preferences.* Players can enjoy casual free-for-alls, ranked matches, and custom games, as well as various party modes and time-limited events. These modes provide a variety of ways to play and keep the gameplay experience fresh and entertaining. The frequent in-game events, featuring unique challenges and themed content, add an extra layer of excitement and replayability.4. Robust Online Play and Community:The game‚Äôs robust online infrastructure supports smooth and competitive multiplayer matches. With cross-platform play across consoles, PC, and mobile devices, Brawlhalla allows players to compete and team up with friends regardless of their platform. The active and passionate community contributes to a vibrant online scene, with regular tournaments and a dedicated player base that keeps the competitive spirit alive.5. Fair Free-to-Play Model:Brawlhalla employs a fair and generous free-to-play model that provides substantial content without requiring purchases.* While the game offers cosmetic items and Legends through microtransactions, all gameplay content, including the entire roster of Legends, can be unlocked through gameplay or in-game currency. This approach ensures that players can enjoy the full experience without spending money, making it accessible to a broad audience.Cons:1. Visual Simplicity and Art Style:While the game‚Äôs visuals are colorful and appealing, they may appear simplistic compared to more graphically advanced titles. The art style, though charming and functional, lacks the detailed animations and polish seen in some of the game‚Äôs competitors. This simplicity can be seen as both a strength, in terms of clarity during chaotic battles, and a limitation for players seeking more visually impressive experiences.2. Lack of Single-Player Depth:The single-player offerings in Brawlhalla are relatively limited and may not fully satisfy those looking for a robust solo experience. While there are training modes, offline matches, and bot challenges, the game primarily shines in its multiplayer aspects. Players who prefer single-player content might find the game‚Äôs offerings somewhat lacking in depth and variety.3. Repetitive Gameplay Over Time:Despite the variety of game modes and Legends, the core gameplay loop in Brawlhalla can become repetitive over extended play sessions. The game‚Äôs focus on fast-paced, action-packed matches means that players might experience a sense of repetition, particularly if they stick to one or two favorite Legends. Regular updates and events help mitigate this to some extent, but the core mechanics remain largely consistent.4. Learning Curve for Competitive Play:While the game is accessible to newcomers, mastering the intricacies of competitive play can present a significant learning curve. Advanced players will find a deep meta-game with complex strategies and mechanics that require dedication and practice to fully understand. This steep learning curve may be daunting for casual players who wish to compete at higher levels but struggle to keep up with experienced opponents.Conclusion:Brawlhalla offers an engaging and accessible platform fighting experience with a diverse roster, fun gameplay, and a fair free-to-play model. Its vibrant online community and variety of game modes provide endless fun for players of all skill levels, though its visual simplicity and limited single-player content may not appeal to everyone. Whether you‚Äôre looking for a casual brawl or a competitive challenge, Brawlhalla delivers a solid and enjoyable experience that continues to evolve and entertain.Jump into the action-packed world of Brawlhalla and explore its diverse Legends, accessible mechanics, and thrilling multiplayer battles. Whether you‚Äôre a casual fighter or a competitive warrior, Brawlhalla offers a dynamic and fun platform fighter experience that‚Äôs worth your time.

This game is like snorting cocaine with glass shards and rubbing alcohol mixed together.......let me explain. If you ever decide to really invest yourself into getting good at this game, you need 3 things, #1: strong emotional/anger management, #2: need to have some sort of neurological disorder like autism or ADHD, and #3: Time. explanation for #1: this games community is toxic and obnoxious to say the least, you'll start to get the most pissed off when you go against a mordex or teros main or god forbid a caspian main, ew. People in this game will do ANYTHING for a win, and for them that means, taunting to trigger, playing passive, sig spam, weapon starving, scythe, lance, greatsword, teros, i mean the list could go on. So to sum up the frustration part, you need to have an unshakable and unbreakable mental to do good against the scum of this community. I will note this for the lower playtime newer folk, (there IS a counter to everyone and every play style in this game) its not impossible, thats just the challenge of the game. explanation for #2: I say you need to have adhd or autism because it takes a special kind of brain to keep coming back to this game and to keep progressing your skill level through all the ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• this game hands out. don't get me wrong the game is fun and addictive but its hard to get ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• on so hard by someone and continue to cue into another match, especially if your playing ranked. to sum up this part, this game requires a LOT of patience and dedication if you wanna be plat or diamond. I will say, ive been playing this game for a little over a thousand hrs now and i can say that it feels really good to be good, you will reach a certain point when your start to notice your not getting rolled by sig spam and overly aggressive gold mordex mains, and even if you lose to those gold mordex mains it stops effecting you, and you just say gg wp and move on, and this is because you put your ego beside and are able to see why you lost and improve upon it instead of just getting mad that you lost. and to transition into #3: Time, time is honestly everything you need to get good at this game or anything for that matter, if you spend enough time on it you will surely "get good" eventually. This game is a try hard sweaty ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• fest of fun and ball twisting torture. if your just getting into this game, (don't turn to the dark side, ever.) what is the dark side? all that ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• i listed above that you'll be going against, thats the dark side, the side that feeds into the worst and most toxic parts of this community, playing into the dark side will take you far in lower ranks but as soon as you start going against high plat to diamond, you will get rolled 80% of the time. you can win games without playing scummy, i know i know, its hard to believe that playing honorably with sportsmenship and respect can win games but it can be done. so uhh, yeah over all 8/10 would play again.

This game's fundamentals are really good for the most part. I enjoy playing this game. HOWEVER, I am NOT recommending it for several reasons:1.) Over the years this game has existed, I believe that this game has experienced a lot of bloat, in my opinion over the years, it has accumulated way too many legends (fighters) that unless you play constantly, it's quite hard to keep up with what they do, let alone know how to fight against them. Same thing with maps, most maps are just the same thing (so it's harder to ban that thing if you don't like a certain style of stage). Now, some people might like this constant flow of new content, and it is pretty exciting when new stuff comes out, however, once you get used to it being there, it just makes things more confusing. I couldn't imagine getting into this game as a new player and playing Ranked.2.) This one is small, but IMO important. This game has horrible accessibility (and honestly settings in general). If you have eyesight problems, this is gonna be a tough game for you. Luckily, it's at least easy to modify map background (to either replace them or blur/darken them) but a player should not have to do that to see what's going on! And this doesn't solve the issue of the skins anyways, since some blend in so much, and if you have the same special color as your opponent? Good luck keeping track. Another great thing is that there are skins that totally change the animations and look of the legends, so if you didn't catch the tiny text at the start of the match which tells you what legend it actually is, have fun figuring out their moveset.3.) The netcode. This is just horrible, it's gotten a little better than it was years back, but it's still really really bad. Random teleportation, hits not counting, getting booted out of matches, completely losing connection to the server randomly.... If you get unlucky, say goodbye to your ELO/your fun match.4.) The toxicity. The game has emotes, which are fun, and can be really cute, however, it seems that this game somehow really breeds negativity and toxicity, because it seems 9/10 people I meet on this game are totally salty and toxic whether they win or lose! There used to be a chat, so the developers decided that the best way to fix the toxicity issue with chat is to just remove it. So on the special occasion you do actually meet someone cool and nice, you have to jump through 5 hoops to actually befriend them...And now, for some positives:While the game does have ingame spending, you aren't forced into it much, coins to buy legends/colors are pretty easy to come by, and you get a special currency for participating in ranked, which gives you access to exclusive colors, weapon skins, emotes etc., which is a really nice reward.The game's balance (apart from the bloat) feels pretty good to me as a layman (I have around ~1500elo = Gold 2 ish).The character variety might appeal to some people as there's a very wide range (greek-ish mythology-ish, some straight up crossovers, modern characters, all races and genders represented, and the playstyles can vary quite a bit too!).The gameplay itself is really fun too. Each weapon (including unarmed) has 7 standard moves and then 3 signature moves per character per weapon (except for unarmed, which is standard across legends). I personally really enjoy the addition of the throw mechanic, where you can throw your weapon/gadget at your opponent to do a bit of damage, knockback, and interrupt their attack, which feels really satisfying to pull off in combos.I also like how the game support couch co-op.There's also gigantic lobby possibilities, but honestly I don't know how fun that is with skilled players, as it's mostly a signature spamming fest. 2v2 is really fun though if you have a friend who you can play with.It's honestly a shame the game has so many problems that are so severe, since I feel like the potential is there for it to be truly great, but the company is driven by other incentives :/

I wouldn't get into this game, because once you start reaching a certain point (like high gold onwards to plat) the playstyle that is encouraged is EXTREMELY passive. A lot of playing keep away from your opponents, and players often will let you chase them around the map for a long time and wait to punish you as you get frustrated.That is strategy, and would be fine if it didn't rubberband relatively frequently, despite my flawless internet connection and proximity to Brawlhalla servers. For some reason, some maps lag incredibly hard. I've noticed that this game doesn't run well on an M2 air as well, which is absolutely nuts.I got to mid-gold in spite of these issues. Unfortunately, I've come to realize that the game isn't really worth playing in this state.

This game is simply not fun. This is a highly competitive game, and probably you won't have much fun playing it. It's not simply because it is competitive, it is because putting in the time to get good at this game mostly won't be rewarding. There is a lot of problems with this game which shouldn't there be in a competitive game like this.1. There is a huge amount of players that just spam heavy/signature attacks. Beating them takes real skill if you want to play the right way which most players won't be inclined to since they are here to have fun. This creates a huge learning curve. This wasn't always such a big problem but lately %80 of playerbase spam attacks and don't see a problem with it. This takes too much fun out of the game. Why learn combos and string attacks if you can just get to platinum rank ( 2nd highest rank) just by spamming attacks?2. Often times you will hit but it won't register, you will dodge but not to the direction you wanted to, you will press dodge but it won't for the hell of it. This game has a big input delay problem. This immensely competitive game ,where even a split second reaction can decide the outcome, has fps drop issues which is not that uncommon among players. You can just go ahead and search in google, you will see so many players seeking solution and not finding it. Do you have a good network and high end pc ? Sometimes that won't matter unfortunately.3. Cherry on top is devs just don't care anymore about these issues, they are only looking after money. There is no fixes for the problems I mentioned above, but there is always a battle pass to purchase right next to each other. So as long as they are making money who cares about fun right?So after 500 hours of rage, exhaustion and little amount of reward/fun. I don't recommend this game simply because it is not that much fun that will worth your time that you will put into it. So do not even begin, don't fall into this pit. If you don't die to spammers, you will die because your character won't obey your input. Stay clean

Before I start this review, I would like to make a short statement:I am a Melee player. For me, SSBM is the best platform fighter and any deviation from it is simply an inferior decision.With that being said, Brawlhalla is a really good game.It's not a Smash killer because it's not trying to be Smash at all. That's also a huge reason why it's not dead. When a game tries to be Smash, it doesn't work out. This game has decided to go in its own direction which has resulted in a weapons, combo and movement system coupled with gamemodes that are all unique to this game and really well executed.Anyone who says "If you like Smash you'll like this" is wrong in the sense that this isn't free Smash. The similarities essentially end after the fact they both exist in the platform fighter genre.The game is like the opposite of Melee but executed so well that I just can't not recommend it.On top of that, the devs are amazing and I have nothing but respect for what they've done. The free to play experience is so good. You get a good rotation of characters and just playing enough games with friends nets you enough to get a legend. The online experience for this game is really good overall as well. Items are also not overtuned and can be useful but they aren't nearly as overpowered as they are in Smash. The other gamemodes are all pretty good too. There isn't really a lot I can criticise about the game.There are 2 things I have some minor problems with though. A small one is I would really like the ability to bind the right stick to light attacks. The other is a more major issue and the fact that it's not completely uncommon for disconnects to happen during matches. The reconnecting system to a match you've disconnected on has a chance of working but I have no real reason to trash on the game about something that I personally put under the "Nice to have" category.Short version: The game is in the same genre as Smash but saying it's "free Smash" is an insult to the game because it's so unique. F2P experience is good. Online is good. Casual experience is good. Game is good.
